 4. PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Economic and Financial Analysis Economic Rationale for Project Investment 4.1 Sri Lanka's education system, despite its excellent coverage, has low internal and external efficiency. The quality of its output is below the levels that could be expected from the country's high literacy levels and coverage of education, and the substantial inputs made to the system. In large measure these inefficiencies relate to the quality and use of teachers. The uncontrolled recruitment of teachers has led to an exceptionally high proportion of the teaching force being inexperienced and untrained; on the other hand there are mismatches in the availability and use of teachers in different parts of the country, for different types of school, and in different subject specialties. Teacher absenteeism is high, and there is lack of continuity in that teachers transfer frequently away from difficult areas. In addition, many of those teachers who have been trained are less than fully productive because the neglected teacher training system is ineffective. The training system is fragmented, uncoordinated, and has a high unit cost. 4.2 In view of these inadequacies, it was concluded that policy measures to improve teacher deployment coupled with an investment project in teacher education would have positive impact in many areas. The project will help the government implement its program to manage teacher recruitment, employment and deployment, using the Ready Reckoner resource allocation formula, a school consolidation policy based on school mapping, and a revised teacher transfer policy, thus rationalizing deployment of almost 190,000 teachers; it will require that all teachers be trained before entering the service, ensuring over the next five years that all of the teaching force is pre-trained, rationalizing and upgrading the training levels of teacher education system. Research in Sri Lanka shows that upgrading of teachers has a major impact on student learning and quality of education. 4.3 Comparative analyses were made of various scenarios of modifying student- teacher ratios and salary costs, as well as of various ways of providing cost-effective teacher education and training. The conclusions of the selected scenario, described below, constitute a basis of the Government's new strategies, and show that the strategies are both feasible and highly cost effective. 45
 4.4 The Project will: * make teacher employment more efficient by standardizing teacher recruitment, deployment, and training activities, as well as rationalizing teacher numbers and redirecting savings to other priority educational objectives; * make the teacher education system more effective by making it demand driven to better address national, district, and school level needs, by rationalizing the geographical distribution of institutions; * make the teacher education system more efficient through rationalizing the number of teacher training institutions thus lowering the unit cost while maximizing the utilization and making the institutions multi-functional. Also, by increasing student:staff ratios, reducing non-academic staff, rationalizing residential facilities according to demand, and increasing the proportion of day students (thereby reducing boarding costs); * improve the quality of education for 4.1 million students in primary, secondary, and collegiate levels by upgrading teachers, consequently increasing school outcomes and reducing the cycle cost; and * make education more equitable and rationalize teacher distribution according to school needs. 4.5 Project Benefits: The project provides benefits in the following overlapping areas, related to the different activities it supports. (a) Teacher deployment. This component produces substantial savings from reducing the numbers of teachers in the system, because of declining enrollment, controlled teacher recruitment, more equitable allocation of teachers and a policy to increase student:teacher ratios in schools. It also leads to improved education since a more equitable allocation system will provide trained teachers for children who at present have inadequate teaching. School consolidation also leads to reduced expenditure on non- teaching staff. Potential savings from this group of activities (that is total expenditure on salaries compared with what would have been spent on present trends) over the period 1996-05 could reach Rs 1.6 billion. (b) Components related to teacher education: These components provide for rationalizing the structure and organization of pre-service and in-service teacher education; improving teacher education programs; training teacher educators and administrators; rehabilitating, expanding and rationalizing 46
 teacher training institutions; and strengthening teacher education management. They will give rise to benefits in three ways: * they will improve the quality of teacher education, by better programs and better teacher educators, thus improving the quality of education which the trained teachers themselves provide; * they will increase the cost-effectiveness of teacher education, through better situated training colleges which will allow a greater proportion of students to be non-residential, through better planning of teacher education, through increased trainee:trainer ratios, through shorter courses, and through better use of facilities. The increased cost effectiveness will allow the system to double its annual output of trained teachers with only an increase of 14% in recurrent costs; * the project will increase the number of teachers trained, both by increasing capacity for training teachers and by providing as part of the project direct, continuing education to an increased number of teachers. Thus by the end of the project most of the teachers in the system will have been given basic teacher training, and many undergone upgrading. This will have important benefits both for the general quality of education and for the equity with which it is provided. (c) All components: In their effect on ensuring that there are trained teachers available for the majority of students (and through the reallocation of the savings from reducing the numbers of teachers to improve availability of quality inputs), the project will improve general education levels. These are the most important benefits to be derived from the project: the unquantifiable effects for the quality of life and the economy, with the indirect social and economic effects that stem from better education. However, the improved quality will also reduce repetition and drop-out, increasing the efficiency of the education system. In the best case (see below) benefits from increased internal efficiency could total over Rs 2 billion over the period 1996-05. 4.6 Fiscal Sustainability: The Project and the programs it supports have a broadly neutral fiscal impact. The declining enrollment in general education (both primary and secondary) due to demographic trends, with the low STR of 24:1 and the excess of teachers in the system, increases the need to rationalize use of education sector resources at the school, provincial, and central levels. At the same time, the tight fiscal condition and the increasing public budget deficit further intensify the need to rationalize Government expenditures and, in turn, put more pressure on the MEHE and the provinces to rationalize teacher numbers and their distribution through recruitment control and consolidation of small schools. Teacher employment rationalization, linking application of the mechanism to resource allocations, would generate substantial sector cost reductions. Annex 12 contains an analysis of the project activities and of the reforms they will support, their outcome, and (where possible) estimates of their costs and benefits. During 47
 the period 1996-2005, aggregate salary expenditure (using the recent 1995 salary scale) could be reduced by Rs 1.6 billion if teacher recruitment is controlled as planned, as the total number of teachers and school administrators would be reduced by 25,000 by 2005 (Figures 4.1 and 4.2). If project-related reforms are carried out filly, and the improvement in education progressively reduces repetition rates substantially, total fiscal savings during the period 1996-2005 could in the best case add further savings of between Rs 2 and 3 billion, making total savings for the 10 years over Rs 4 billion, or US$74 million, equivalent to the costs of the project and incremental expenditures on teacher training. When the unquantifiable (but large) benefits from improved levels of general education in the population at large are factored in, the project benefits are massive. The saving in education salaries would be re-invested in desperately needed quality components such as school supplies and teaching materials, increased teacher training, and to develop support and incentive schemes to motivate teacher transfers to remote and hardship areas.  4.7 The project's largest benefits by far come from improving the quality of education received by the 4.1 million students, by improving teacher competence. However, improved education quality also increases internal efficiency. A recent study of education in Sri Lanka (draft 1995) showed that the results of the 0 level exam were strongly associated with teacher qualifications. Thus, an investment in improving teacher qualifications is expected to increase efficiency of student progression through the system, reducing costly repetition and drop-outs, improve examination results, and lead to reductions in the system's cost. Analysis described in Annex 12 shows the potential extent of such savings, between Rs 2 and 3 billion in the most optimistic case. 4.8 There will be substantial benefits from more efficient operation of the teacher training institutions. The rationalization of teacher training institutions would lead to a reduction in their residential places by one third of enrollment (now 100 percent residential) and so in reduced running costs (currently residential facilities account for over 50 percent of institutional operating costs). Furthermore, the application of other cost- effectiveness measures -- such as standardizing programs, offering several programs in one location, having larger enrollments and increasing trainee:teacher educator ratios to 15: 1, maximizing the use of standardized equipment and facilities, reducing the number of support staff, reducing service costs through better location of institutions, and privatizing food services -- would result in much lower annual recurrent costs. Studies in other Asian countries that have rationalized their teacher training institutions through similar projects have shown that the operation of fewer and more cost effective institutions has amortized investment costs in about ten years and given long-term sustained lower operation costs. 4.9 Fiscal Sustainability of Teacher Training Reforms. The operational costs of the rationalized teacher education system for the period 1994-2005, which were estimated on the basis of the expected capacity needs, are reasonable, affordable and sustainable. The proposed scheme was shown during project preparation to be the most cost-effective means of achieving project objectives of several options that were analyzed. Annual recurrent costs of the institutions of teacher education after rationalization (even with a doubling of output) are expected to increase from Rs 221 million in 1995 to Rs 254 million after the end of the project in 2002, and then to decline slightly in real terms, reaching Rs 252 million in 2005. Had the system operated in its present manner, annual recurrent costs for the increased throughput of students would have reached Rs 314 million in 2002 and 367 million by 2005. The operating costs of teacher education programs represent 7 percent of the total MEHE budget and 3.3 percent of the total education budget. If the education budget grows as the Government projects at 3 percent per year, recurrent costs of teacher education programs -- 14 percent higher in real term at the end of the project, with a doubling of output -- will represent a smaller proportion than at present of the education budget. Thus the combined expansion and rationalization of teacher education programs and institutions is a desired, affordable and sustainable action (Annex 36). 49
 4.10 Project activities also have other benefits that are difficult to quantify: * Reassignment of qualified teachers to deprived areas brings substantial education benefits for the (mainly poor) children from those areas. * The reallocation to quality inputs and maintenance of salary savings resulting from the stricter application of the RR would contribute to the positive impact on education attainment and related effects. * The increased funds for building maintenance will lead to long-term savings in building replacement. B. Risks 4.11 This policy-based project involves risks mainly related to policy implementation. During project preparation it was agreed by all levels of government, teacher educators, teachers and teacher associations that addressing teacher education and teacher deployment policies was long overdue, and that the programs proposed were acceptable. However, within the strongly political climate of Sri Lanka, circumstances can change rapidly. The main risks envisaged are: - The political or bureaucratic commitment to the application of new teacher deployment policies might not be fully implemented in some provinces. This applies especially to those provinces which are overstaffed and which might be reluctant to fully implement the Ready Reckoner formula. Similarly, some provinces may be reluctant to redirect salary savings. If savings are lower, the allocation for desperately needed quality inputs could, in turn, be reduced; * Some schools in the rural areas could still have inequitable allocations of teachers if the incentive system is not fully implemented. Due to national fiscal difficulties, a few provinces might attempt to use the incentive funds for other uses unless proper control and accountability are fully implemented; * Various political forces might resist rationalization of institutions. Others may oppose the implementation of firmer policies for teacher education hiring and deployment along with the stricter work criteria all part of the a national teacher strategy that would increase responsiveness to actual needs while increasing cost-effectiveness; and * Past project experience shows that implementation of agreed policies is difficult and time consuming in Sri Lanka. However, based on the consensus reached and as a result of the substantial participation and intensive technical dialogue undertaken during project preparation, it is estimated that these risks have been reduced. Nevertheless, the project is likely to suffer, as other projects, from the cumbersome bureaucracy and potential implementation 50
 delays experienced by all projects in Sri Lanka. Government has already demonstrated its intent to address the administrative and staff issues by the appointment of the project coordination Director in December 1995. 4.12 The Government recognizes that ignoring or avoiding the issues in teacher education would be worse than attempting the changes proposed. MEHE's efforts to date have demonstrated a willingness to tackle policy concerns. These efforts suggest that the risks are worth taking and that there is political and professional will for the project to be implemented on schedule. 51

Part I - BACKGROUND: In 1983, the Ministry of Education issued a comprehensive set of Guidelines on Teaching Staff Requirements, using a formula - generally referred to as the Ready Reckoner (RR). The policy, which applies to all schools, is designed to ensure optimum and equitable deployment and utilisation of available teachers. Some minor modifications were made in 1990. School staffing entitlements are calculated separately for: * the number of students in the Primary Cycle (Kg-G5); * the number of students in the Secondary Cycle (G6-1 1); * the number of classes in the Collegiate Cycle (G12-13). It is the responsibility of the principal of each school to calculate the number of teachers needed and to complete and forward the requisite forms to the Divisional Office. Forms are sent to MEHE for collation and verification. Details of school entitlements are then forwarded to Provincial Education Offices. Representations may be made to MERE to review the allocation to a school or schools in a province. Actual numbers allocated under the RR for each province are submitted to the Finance Commission by MEHE as the basis for determining the teacher salary component of the block grants. A revised process has been developed for implementation in conjunction with the MIS system to be introduced in 1996. FACTORS AFFECTING ALLOCATIONS: Specific factors that have been taken into account in developing and applying the RR include: Primary * class size is 30; * grade 1 and 2 have 25 contact hours per week (5 per day), grades 3-5 have 30 contact hours per week (6 per day); * a primary teacher nornally teaches 35 periods (out of a weeldy total of 40 periods) the remaining 5 periods being for the teaching of English (by a specialist teacher); * special provision is made for small primary schools with enrolments below 50 (e.g., a school with 25 students will have 3 staff - principal, teacher, and specialist English teacher). 56
 Secondary * class size is 35; * grades 6-11 have 30 contact hours per week (6 per day); * a secondary teacher normally teaches 32 periods (out of a weeldy total of 40 periods). Collegiate * grades 12-13 have 30 contact hours per week (6 per day); * collegiate class size is normally 25-30 students - smaller classes may be formed (minimum of 15 students) where students are unable to attend a larger school within a 5 mile radius, the number of teachers being 3 (one for each stream); * staffing is based on one teacher per class; * a collegiate teacher normally teaches 32 periods (out of a weekly total of 40 periods); * grade 13 students are allowed to repeat the year, but are not permitted to attend school on a regular basis - such students are not taken into account in calculating staff entitlements. OTHER FACTORS AFFECTING ALLOCATIONS: Regardless of size, all schools have a principal and a teacher(s) of English, in addition to the normal staff entitlement. See Note 1, below. There is no teaching allocation for principals, regardless of the size of the school. Depending on the size of the school, provision is made for sectional heads, an assistant principal, and a deputy principal. Teaching responsibilities for supervisory positions are as follows: * Subject Co-ordinator: 10 hours per week; * Grade Co-ordinator: 15 hours per week; * Supervisors: 10 hours per week; * Assistant Principal: 7 hours per week. An additional teacher is allocated to schools with an enrolment of 500+ in grades 6-11. Schools do not have administrative or clerical support. Teachers assigned to provide such support may be relieved of part or all of their teaching duties. It is generally acknowledged that this is an inappropriate use of teaching staff and that the strategy is not cost-effective. Part 6 Incentives: The plan would be based on the newly-formulated categorisation of schools into four groups, according to degrees of hardship. This plan would: * differential allowances based on the degree of hardships (15% of salary in most difficult schools and 10% in difficult plus educational material support); 60
 * differential location allowances on an escalating basis corresponding to the years of service in a particular location; * consideration of years of service in less favourable schools to be used as one of the main criteria for transfer to more favourable schools; * support for teacher travel and housing (local standards); * special provision to facilitate teacher access to study opportunities, including payment of partial to full fees and assistance with travel to study centres; and * support for the education of the teacher's children where there is no secondary school available locally. Part 7 Monitorin SteDs: The monitoring steps for the RR and quality inputs would be: * present staffing per school/district/zone and province based on the cadre analysis as completed by MEBE during year one of the project. A survey identifying the essential needs by subject and classroom would be undertaken during the first six months of the project and thereafter justifications on the meeting of such target would have to be demonstrated annually; * the actual cadre would be revised on an annual basis to meet enrolments. Once the cadre matched the proposed STR of 27:1 at primary and 22:1 at secondary new goals and long-term national goal of 30:1 and 25:1 would be set; * the transfer policy would be implemented annually transferring teachers first from overstaffed to understaffed schools within a district/zone/province. Annually about three months prior to school opening the surplus teachers from the various provinces would be submitted to the Transfer Board for re-assignment to other provinces to fill vacancies. At the secondary and upper primary levels efforts should be to have, within a period of about three years, teachers match the subject needs. Each school/district/zone should have a plan to match subject needs. The plan would be verified annually as part of the RR review; * Provinces would have to report annually and present the following: a list of quality inputs awarded school by school with these inputs matching the following goals: 3% in 1997; 4% in 1998; 5% in 1999; and 6% in year 2000. Administrative units not meeting the target would have to justify the reasons and if they continued not to match the national quality needs, alternative ways to deliver these quality needs to the schools could be considered to ensure equitable allocation of quality goods to all the students. Quality inputs would be based on: student unit costs by grade and by level. A quality allocation would also be made for each teacher by level. * The monitoring activities would determine how the staff and administrator numbers could be made to fit the cadre. At the start of the project each unit that was understaffed would be given the needed staff to fit the cadre. Each under staffed unit would have to submit a plan on how they could reach the cadre. The over staffed school/district/zone and province units would have to submit a plan, with a maximum of three years, showing how they would reduce their staff to arrive at the recommended cadre; and * these target would be adjusted annually to respond to actual needs and specific priorities. Certain essential targets to meet would be: no. of textbooks; no. of library books; adequate chalkboards; adequate supply of chalk and essential supplies; availability of writing materials for the students; adequacy of science and mathematics materials; resource materials for social studies, language and other subject teaching (these would be established by NIE during the first six months of the project); desk and seats for all the children; required sports equipment; adequate drinking and washing facilities; etc. These goals would be reviewed about every second year to ensure standards and adequate supply of essential materials and quality inputs in the schools. A main target would also be to increase equity among all the schools to increase the learning opportunities of particularly the rural, slum area and poor children. 61

Ministry of Education & Higher Education, "lsurupaya", Battaramulla. 31.03.1995 National Policy on Teachers Transfers The Goverrunent has decided to formulate a National Policy on Teachers Transfers with a view to ensuring the implementation of the educational activities meaningfully and providing for the maximum welfare and benefit of the student and teacher population. The Cabinet of Ministers has decided that the National Policy should be based on the following criteria: 1. Since education should be pupil centered the needs of the pupils should be given priority on all occasions. 2. Since the improvement of the quality of education depends on the knowledge and the skills of the teachers, the policy on teachers transfers should promote the development of skills and knowledge in teachers. 3. The policy on teachers transfers should be formulated in a manner to ensure the professional security, academic freedom and the job satisfaction of the teachers and should provide for the teachers to serve with a considerable degree of confidence without the fear of being transferred out unjustifiably. 4. One of the main objectives of this policy should be to minimize the regional discrepancies observed in the process of education. 5. The policy on transfers should ensure an equitable distribution of the human resources in the field of education so as to make such scarce resources available to the public at the periphery. 6. Such policy should lead to the maximum utilization of the scarce human resource available in the sector through a proper management of resources. 7. Other than in the instances where a transfer is made to facilitate the procedure when disciplinary action is being taken or is being contemplated against a teacher, all transfers of teachers should be made on a recommendation made by a duly constituted teachers transfer board. 8. Transfers of teachers should be effected only on the recommendations of a duly constituted transfer board other than in the cases where disciplinary action is being take or is being contemplated against a teacher and where transfers are made on a request by a teacher for reasons of ill-health and on exigencies of service. The transfer boards should be informed of any transfers made on exigencies of service within a period of 2 weeks from the date of the letter effecting the transfer. 9. Teachers transfer boards should be established at the following levels: * Zonal Education Office. * Provincial/Additional Provincial Education Office. * Line Ministry. In addition to the members of the teachers transfer boards to be appointed in terms of Section 5 of Chapter Ill of Establishments Code, a representative of every Teachers Union registered under the Trade Unions Ordinance and whose membership is serving in more than one Province in the Island should be appointed as members of the transfer board. 10. Classification of Schools - The Schools are classified as given below: * Very congenial * Congenial * Non-congenial * Difficult 11. The line Ministry in consultation with the Provincial Ministries of Education shall classify the schools as per above. 65
 12. Time Schedule - Other than in the cases specified under para 2 above, the transfers of teachers should be effected only at the beginning of a calendar year with a view to minimizing inconveniences caused to the students and the teachers. 13. Calling for Applications - Applications for annual transfers of teachers should be called for between 1 st June and 30th June of each year. 14. Meetings of the Transfers Boards - The transfers boards to consider the applications received shall meet between 1st and 31st of August each year. 15. Collection of data and information - authorities concerned shall collect and compile information and data relating to teachers transfers and vacancies in respect of all Schools before 31st of July each year. 16. Issue of letters - Letters on annual transfers shall be issued by 15 of September each year. 17. Appeals - Appeals shall be received during the period between 15th September to 15th October each year. 18. Decision by the Appeal Board - Appeal Board shall consider all the appeals between 15th October to 30th November and the decision of the board shall be conveyed before 30th of November. 19. Teachers transfers may be effected for reasons of ill-health, on mutual requests and requests by teachers on very valid grounds outside the above procedure but, within the framework laid down by the National Policy. 20. The provisions of the Chapter III of the establishments shall be applicable to all transfers of teachers other than in the cases specified in this Circular and such provisions should be followed in all instances. 21. The implementation of the Policy on teachers transfers. The authorities should ensure that every teacher completes the minimum period of service in a School nominated by the Standing Committee as stipulated in the Sri Lanka Teachers Service Minute. The minimum period of service in respect of diflicult schools shall be 3 years and in respect of non-congenial schools, this period should be 4 years. The maximum period of time a teacher should serve in a congenial school shall be 8 years and shall be 6 years in a very congenial school. 22. The application for a transfer on reasons of ill-health by a teacher, shall be accompanied by a medical certificate of a specialist in the respective field and the clinic cards. The risk factors approved by the World Health Organization shall be accepted as valid reasons for transfers on reasons of ill-health in the case of expectant mothers. In addition to the personal health of the teacher concerned, the health of the following members of the family of the teacher may be taken into consideration. * Spouse. - Children. * Dependent parents if the teacher is not married 23. Whenever possible the transfers to the officers of the Sri Lanka Principals' Service and the Sri Lanka Educational Administrative Service shall be made parallel to the National Policy on teachers transfers. 24. First Appointment - At the recruitment of teachers the first appointment shall be make to a school in the following two categories: * Difficult. * Non-congenial. 25. Miscellaneous - All teachers who have not so far served in a non congenial or difficult station shall be subjected to the minimum period of service in such a school. However, teachers of over 53 years of age shall not be so transferred. 26. All transfer boards shall prepare a manual of procedure in terms of the National Policy provided by this Circular and shall follow such manual of procedure in all instances. The Cabinet of Ministers at its meeting held on 18th January 1995 has approved the National Policy laid down by this Circular and all authorities effecting teachers transfers are required to follow this policy. 66

Figure 1: Percentage of Trainees In Teacher Training Institutions in 1994 COE 6% TTC 5% Program Costs: The cost of all teacher training programs was estimated at Rs 206 million in 1994, representing 6 percent of the education recurrent budget. However, the magnitude and distribution of costs become quite different with the inclusion of additional costs such as trainees full salaries in TTCs, student stipends in COEs. The total cost almost doubles when these expenditures are added to reach Rs. 366 million representing 10% of the sectoral budget. The TTC share increased substantially to 48 percent and both the TTC and COE cost amounted to 70 percent of all program costs even though they train 11 percent of all trainees, while NIE with 24 percent of costs, trains 81 percent of the trainees (Figure 3). Program Unit Cost: Cost analysis among different programns is based on unit cost estimnates of expenditure per trainee in the teacher training institutions. It is difficult to estimate the unit cost on the bases of equivalent full-time students as the mixture of full-time, and part-time distance education training modies across different types of institutions precludes the determination of a uniform base. However, the difference in the programs' unit costs is so vast that a refinement would not change the scale of such variations. 3. The expenditure per student in the TTCs is by far the largest followed by the COEs, the universities, and then by NIE (Figure 4). The unit cost differentials are usually attributed to several factors such as program type, duration, equipment used, staff deployment, and mode of delivery. However, the substantially high UC of the TTCs is due to the massive cost of trainee salaries which represents more than two thirds of the TTCs' total cost. Funding policies for institutions are unclear and appear to bear no consistent relationship to actual enrollments or the number of staff actually required in a given year. Cost Implications of Residential Facilities: The policy of providing residential services to all trainees of the COEs and most of the trainees in the TTCs is very expensive. The isolated location of teacher training institutions increases the costs of all the services and makes staffing more difficult and 70
 costly. For example, expenditure related to the residential facilities in one of the COEs represented over 50% of the total institution's recurrent budget. This residential isolation also makes the necessary integration of future teachers into the community more difficult. Residential facilities increase overhead expenditure and require substantial resources for running costs and salaries of additional service workers. A vast segment of the cost comes from the large number of non-academic staff and service workers in these institutions, who are required to support and maintain these facilities. The ratio of academic to non- academic staff in 1994 was 1:1 in the TTCs and 1:3 in the COEs. 5. Under-utilization of the residential facilities in these institutions adds to the overall costs and increases their unit cost. In 1994, the COEs, which offer residential facilities to all their first and second year students, only used 74% of this residential capacity (third year students do their internship year in schools). Capacity utilization rates vary substantially among the COEs. Similar variations in capacity utilization are found in the TTCs. Some of the institutions in remote and rural areas, which were established under political pressure, have very low rates of utilization and are run with high operating costs. As in other Asian countries, Sri Lanka needs to develop a plan for the relocation of teacher training institutions to increase cost-effectiveness, reduce boarding according to needs and increase lower-cost day students. 6. High Cost of Low Student:Staff Ratio: The low student:staff ratio in the TTCs and the COEs was 9:1 and 13:1, respectively, in 1994 (which declined further in 1995) increases overhead expenses and inflates the unit cost of these institutions. In addition, the large number of non-academic staff, required mainly for the residential services offered to the trainees, adds substantially to the recurrent costs of these institutions. In addition, the facilities of the COEs and TTCs which carry out pre- and in-service training programs, respectively, are under-utilized and inefficiently managed. 7. High Cost of Trainees Salaries and Stipends: The current policy of offering payment of full salary to the TTCs trainees and stipends to COEs students is very expensive and adds substantially to the budget. In 1994, the teacher education system cost with student salaries and stipends (Rs 366 million) is almost double the cost without these salaries and stipends. When salaries of trainees are added to the training cost, the TTCs recurrent expenditure increases by almost four times and reaches Rs 175 million and its share to the cost of all programs increases from 22% to 48%. 8. There are no studies on assessment of the private costs of training (e.g. fees, books, transportation, lodging). Stipends are paid universally and independently of such costs. As a result, it is difficult to assess whether the students are receiving more or less than they actually spend for training. The system does not include policies and measures to maximize the cost-effectiveness of the training programs on the bases of actual cost to the Government and to the trainee. 9. Unit Cost Variation among Institutions: There is a vast discrepancy in unit costs within TTCs and COEs. For example, the unit cost of TTCs in the Southern Province is more than three times the unit cost of the TTCs in North Western Province. The differences in the unit cost are partly attributed to different level and type of equipment, facilities, and laboratories in these institutions. Institutions specialized in math, science, and English training have different types of equipment and require specialized teachers who are usually paid higher salaries and allowances. 10. InceTicient Institutional Management: These discrepancies in the institutions' unit cost are further accentuated by differences in the utilization of residential and other facilities. Training of the COEs and TTCs management has been limited and has not focused on cost-effectiveness and how to maximize the utilization of facilities, staff and other resources in the institution. Furthermore, the absence of a special formula based on standard criteria for resource distribution and funding has led to the institutions' annual budgets not reflecting their real requirements and consequently some institutions receive more and others less than their needs. The undesirable practice of relying on untrained teachers to fill vacancies, primarily at the secondary level, needs to be reviewed and professional criteria established 71
 for entry into the service at both primary and secondary levels. The goal of the project is to establish by year 2,000 a fully pre-service and pre-trained teacher supplied system. This has the implication that pre- employment of teacher trainees will have to be stopped and that teachers should be employed on the basis of demand. 11. Within each institution, management is less effective than it should be. Selection criteria for heads of institutions do not emphasize leadership or experience in teacher education. Training in management is not required prior to appointment. The structure of the institutions is not conducive to sharing responsibility or team functioning, which could be beneficial for managing such environments. If teacher education is to become a vital force within the country, appropriate appointments of heads and senior staff and a planned program of staff development are essential in developing strong leadership. 12. Other Asian countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines, have rationalized their teacher training institutions on cost-effective bases by consolidation of institutions, establishment of centralized multi-disciplinary institutions with residential service only for targeted students, contracting some of the support services to the private sector, introducing some user fees with safety nets for the poorer students, and maintaining a student:staff ratio that is based on full utilization of their staff (averaging about 20:1). These measures have reduced unit costs thereby contributing to the cost- effectiveness of the system. Sri Lanka needs to also implement such measures. 13. Cost Effectiveness of Distance Education: The distance education program for teacher education was introduced as a cost-effective approach to clear the backlog of untrained teachers. The program for untrained undergraduates has been supported by SIDA. Providing there is no further massive appointment of untrained undergraduate teachers, the backlog should be cleared by the end of 1998. However, the trained teachers with only a certificate will need to be upgraded to diploma level. The knowledge and experience in distance mode should be used for that purpose in the future. The backlog of untrained graduates is currently being addressed through the universities and NIE Departments of Teacher Education. There are no reliable data on the number of graduates who have yet to complete the post graduate diploma program. Until the preservice P.G. Dip Ed. becomes effective, there will be a number of untrained graduates (albeit greatly reduced) entering the service without a professional qualification. 14. The massive number of distance education students enrolled in NIE has resulted in a relatively low unit cost and consequently little attention is paid to the cost of repetition and to examination outcomes. Around 20 percent of the distance education students do not sit for the examination within the planned time and there are no official data on what happens to those students. Monitoring as well as follow up activities need to be strengthened. 15. Minimum attention is given to the output cost (cost per qualified teacher) i.e. partial and complete failure at the terminal examinations, number of students not sitting for finals, and attrition from courses. Course drop-out represents a high cost to the sector and inflates the resources required to provide an adequate and qualified teacher. In addition, recent impressions are that the teachers trained by means of distance education are weaker than teachers trained at COEs in their teaching practice. However, the distance education program has produced some very valuable training units/modules and these should not be lost but integrated into the pre-service programs. The use of most distance training modules should be sustained and extended to other programs through structured continuous teacher training programs. 16. Distance Education Dependence on Foreign Financing: The distance education program at NIM depends heavily on foreign assistance in its financing. Almost 78 percent of the Rs 66 million total program cost is provided by SIDA. SIDA is currently financing primary basic certificate level math and science courses. However, SIDA plans to cover only primary courses by next year and to phase out all the program by 1998 when the major part of the backlog of untrained teachers would be cleared. SIDA will continue to support continuing education for teachers by means of distance education. 72
 17. Complications of University Teacher Education Cost: The overall unit cost of university education programs (Rs 4,000) is quite low compared with training in the TlCs (Rs 14,000) and COEs (Rs 12,000). However, financial reporting of university teacher education programs is complicated by courses being combined with other faculties and by costs of research and post-graduate courses which make it difficult to separate cost of full-time and part-time courses and to assess equivalent full-time student costs. It is also difficult to obtain accurate data on input for staff who are not specifically dedicated to teacher education programs. Further, there are proportionate costs for administration, library and other services which technically could be attributed to the recurrent cost of teacher education programs. These factors deflate the unit cost and reduce overall costs. 18. High Private Cost of University Teacher Education: Private costs of university programs (which are at post-graduate level) are by far the largest in relation to other teacher training programs. For example, students at the Faculty of Education at Colombo University pay Rs 800 per year for registration, tuition, examination, and field work fees. Students who are enrolled in the part-time Diploma program at the regional centers have to pay Rs 4,500 fee per year. However, the Provinces pay students back half of that fee from the block grants they receive. These expenses bring the total private cost to about Rs 4,200 per year and this represents 7 percent of the annual average salary of the teacher. C:\SRILANKA\SAR496\ANNEXES4\ANEXB.DOC 73

Baaararnulla SECREARY Mz =&=C3 )ess 141 - 50DANE April 24, 1996 Mr. Joseph Wood Vice President South Asia Regional Office World Bank Washington, D.C. Dear Mr. Wood, Re: Teacher Education Policy Statement 1. The Government of Sri Lanka is requesting assistance from the International Development Association through a Teacher Education and Teacher Deployment Project to better meet critical teacher requirements and to upgrade the quality of education. The project will support policy reform and related investments in the education sector. This letter outlines the Government's policies. 2. Sri lanka has had positive, but limited, economic growth over the past decade. At the same time, public expenditure has risen by some 6 percent per annum in real terms between 1985-1994. A significant proportion of the growth in public expenditure has resulted from an expansion of the public service, together with increases in salaries. Growth in the public service has been most marked in the teaching profession. The period 1989 to 1994 saw an increase of some 50,000 teachers, the vast majority of whom were untrained. As a result of this, the quality of the teaching service has declined markedly, the student:teacher ratio has decreased from 28:1 in 1989 to 24:1 in 1994 at the primary level and from 22:1 to 16:1 at the secondary level. The effect of the massive recruitment on salary expenditure was immense. Between 1989 and 1993, newly recruited teachers added over Rs. 1.2 billion (18 percent) to the total salary expenditure. Notwithstanding the major increase in teachers, there are still major shortages in some disciplines and an inequitable distribution of teachers across provinces, schools, and language groups. A further problem arises from the fact that only some 18 percent of new recruits to teaching are trained before entering the service. While significant progress have been made in the training of untrained teachers, through the distance mode, which relies heavily on external donor funds, it is recogrnized that this is, at best, a remedial approach and that all teachers should be trained before entering the service. Regrettably, there are insufficient places and resources within the present system to cater for the initial training requirements and inadequate provision for the ongoing continuing education of teachers in the service. Moreover, the teacher education system is fragmented and largely unresponsive to national needs. While many institutions are overstaffed almost all are in need of more suitable facilities and equipment and the equitable distribution of training in the country requires improvement. 75
 3. Traditionally, Sri Lanka has been a leader in education in Asia. Participation rates to the end of year 10, over 70 percent, are well above neighboring countries. Likewise, Sri Lanka has a proud record in providing places for over 80 percent to grade 11. Progression to collegiate level (years 12-13) now reaches 15 percent. Further, it is planned to extend compulsory education from age 12 to age 16 in 1996. The significance and impact of these achievements has, however, been diluted by the over-supply of untrained and often inappropriately assigned teachers. Apart from the adverse impact on education quality, the additional funds required to meet the salaries of additional teachers have had a negative impact on the provision of suitable quantity and quality of student learning materials, equipment, furniture and general maintenance of the infrastructure. The shortcomings have been most marked in disadvantaged and remote schools. 4. Government has determined that there are two crucial issues which need to be urgently addressed within the system: the rationalization of teacher deployment to improve the quality, equity, and cost effectiveness of the system; and the restructuring and upgrading of teacher education programs. The latter to ensure the availability of trained teachers and to provide for the ongoing professional development of all teachers in the service. Government policies are directed towards these interrelated goals as a priority. At the same time, given the economic outlook, it is recognized that the issues of distributing quality educational materials, increasing equitable allocation of resources to all parts of the country and improvements in the administration and of the financing mechanisms of the education system should be given early attention. However, unless the teacher issues are resolved the impact from these investments could be limited. We note that the education budget absorbed about 11 percent of the national budget and the intent is to maximize its use in the foreseeable future, through corrective measures that address the above listed issues. 5. In regard to teacher deployment, the Govenmuent's medium- to long-term objective is to ensure that all teachers be trained before entering the teaching service. This will require a marked increase in the number of training places. To support this initiative, cost savings will be effected through increasing the student:teacher ratios to 26:1 for primary (grades 1-5) and 22:,1 for secondary (grades 6-13) by 2001. It is estimated that substantial salary savings could result. In addition to meeting part of the cost of the expansion of initial training for teachers, salary savings would also be used to provide additional educational materials to all schools and to support incentives-for teachers in the "non-congenial" and "difficult" schools. 6. In order to ensure a more equitable distribution of teachers, nationally, the Govermnent will reactivate the use of the Ready Reckoner formula, as discussed during the IDA appraisal and ensure that all future teacher allocations are done annually and based upon that revised formula. This will be monitored by the National Cadre Committee with representatives from the Ministry of Education and Higher Education, the Ministry of Finance, the Finance Commission and the provinces. It will also ensure that the recently introduced National Policy on Teacher Transfers is implemented consistently for all teachers. This policy requires that teachers serve a minimum of 4 years in "non-congenial" and 3 years in "difficult" schools. Moreover, the maximum period that teachers can spend in a "very congenial" and a "congenial" schools is 6 and 8 years, respectively. As teacher salaries have improved, Government intends to reduce teacher absenteeism and will initiate ways to relate unsatisfactory attendance to salary payment. 7. As part of the Government's policy on the restructuring of expenditure on salaries, financial allocations to provinces will be related directly to cadre entitlements, calculated on the 76
 basis of the staffing formulae, rather than the number of staff actually employed from year to year. Staffing entitlements and budgetary allocations will be regulated through a representative Cadre Committee. Provinces which are overstaffed will be required to reduce the number of teachers to accord with the approved cadre. Provinces which are understaffed will be provided with increased funding as additional teachers are recruited. The adjustments will be made over a three-year period beginning 1997, with the target student:teacher ratios being in place in all provinces by year 2001. 8. In regard to the goal of restructuring and upgrading of teachers, the Government will implement a number of policy initiatives. The first initiative involves major changes to the structure and organization of teacher education, to be addressed on a national level. A National Authority on Teacher Education (NATE) will be established, the principal functions being the development of national policy, planning and coordination, and the systematic monitoring of teacher education, including the accreditation of programs. NATE will be a semi-autonomous institution under the Minister of Education and Higher Education. NATE will oversee the national integrated system of teacher education, comprising 14 National College of Education (NCOEs), the National Institute of Education (NIE), 4 universities and about 80 Teacher Centers (TC- about 78 type A and 3 type B). The Teacher Centers' principal function will be to service the professional development needs of teachers in the field. Teacher Centers will be an integral part of NCOEs with provision for the delivery of continuing education courses through the distance mode by both NIE and universities. This new organization structure will be introduced in 1996 with the establishment of NATE. 9. The second major policy initiative relates to the nature and quality of teacher education programs. As indicated above, Government will require as a basic employment criterion that all teachers entering the service will have completed an accredited initial (pre-service) teacher training program. It is acknowledged that from time to time it may be necessary to recruit a limited number of untrained teachers to fill emergency vacancies. It is also acknowledged that 750 university graduates could be recruited annually according to needs on the bases of 400 trained and 350 untrained. Even so, the recruits will only be employed, following the application of the Ready Reckoner formula and following a minimum three-month intensive course; they will then be required to take part-time training, principally through the distance education mode, in order to gain their initial qualification. Qualitative improvements in the school system will be further advanced through the provision of a comprehensive program of continuing professional development for all teachers. This provision accords with the recently approved Teachers Service Minute, which requires teachers to participate in planned continuing education courses on a five- year cycle. Such courses will be developed through the training institutions and accredited nationally through NATE, thereby facilitating transfer of credits among institutions. In order to increase the flexibility of staffing for schools, all secondary teachers will be required to be trained to teach one major and at least one minor subject. These policy initiatives will become effective in 1996 and will be monitored on an annual basis. 10. The third major policy area, under teacher education, concems staffing levels and staff development for personnel involved in teacher education. In order to maximize the use of staff resources for teacher education, the minimum student:teacher educator ratio will be set at 15: 1, based on equivalent full-time students. This target will be achieved by 1998 when new NCOEs are scheduled to be operational. A program for extensive staff development for teacher educators and teacher education managers will begin with the development of a comprehensive plan in 1996 and will operate throughout the project. The Government's policy calls for an upgrading of academic staff, including senior executives, over a five-year period to attain a profile of 10-15% first degree, 77
 35-40% Post Graduate Diploma in Education, 45% Masters and 10% PhDs. Provision will also be made for the upgrading of administrative and support staff in institutions. As a further strategy for promoting quality, selection criteria relating to academic staff will be developed and applied consistently. NATE, in collaboration with training institutions, will develop, in 1996, sets of minimum criteria to be applied consistently thereafter during the project. The criteria will cover the selection of teacher educators for the professional development program, the appointment of heads of institutions, initial appointments to the Teacher Educator Service, and promotion within the service. Staff allocations will also be directly linked to enrollments with the number of trainers directly related to the trainee:teacher educator ratio of 15:1 and adjusted accordingly on an annual basis. 11. The rationalization of teacher education institutions is the fourth major policy area which the Government will pursue to improve the quality, equity, and cost effectiveness of teacher education. With the proposed setting up of 5 new NCOEs and over 80 TCs, the number of existing teacher education institutions will be reduced from 31 to 19. In order to expand the number of places for initial training and to increase access and the quality of facilities, 5 new NCOEs will be built in strategic locations. These together with the upgrading and expansion of 9 existing institutions will give a more equitable distribution of institutions across provinces and reduce the proportion of residential places required for trainees by one-third. The Govermment is committed to increasing the number of non-residential places as a means of attracting a wider range of students and of adjusting the unit cost of training. About 80 Teacher Centers will be distributed across provinces, having particular regard to demographic and access factors to enable teachers to attend day and, where necessary, short residential continuing education courses. The centers will be part of the network of NCOEs and will also accommodate the distance education delivery requirements of NIE, Open University, and the Universities of Colombo, Peradeniya and Jaffna, which will form part of the national integrated system. By refurbishing existing facilities of the remaining Colleges of Education, Teachers Training Colleges and Field Study Centers, the need for additional capital development will be reduced. The rationalization of institutions is targeted for completion by 1998, when the new NCOEs are due to begin operating. 12. The strengthening of the management of teacher education constitutes a fifth important policy area for improving the effectiveness and efficiency of teacher education. In this area, the Govemrnent will support two principal initiatives, the first being the determiination of unit cost of different types of prograrns as the basis for establishing realistic budget parameters for training institutions. Annual budgets will, therefore, reflect the range of programs offered by a given institution and be linked to the number of students within each program. The second policy initiative relates to increasing the managerial and financial autonomy of NCOEs, through the allocation of an annual budget and a significant extension of the range of delegation for financial and general management at the institutional level. The process will begin in 1996 as part of the budget analysis, be piloted in 1997 and be applied to all institutions in 1998, with regular monitoring and annual reporting to MEHE. 13. Finally, Government would implement recent initiatives for rationalization of teacher numbers and deployment within non economical circumstances. These measures would include: (i) consolidation of smaller primary schools; (ii) training all primary teachers to teach all subjects including English; (iii) following training, phasing out of specialist English language teachers in smaller primary schools; ( (iv) eliminating the position of principal in schools with five teachers or less; (v) consolidating secondary A level classes with 15 or less students in any stream; (vi) consolidating small secondary schools with less than 35 students; (vii) undertaking special recruitment of Tamil medium teachers on a contract basis; (viii) undertaking special recruitment of 78
 university graduates according to identified subject specialist shortages; and (ix) introducing a post-graduate Diploma in Education as an initial training course for an identified number of graduates nnually prior to their employment as teachers. These school consolidation and English training measures are expected to release over 6,850 teaching and administrative positions and will accelerate the attrition and reduce the teaching force by over 25,000 teachers and administrators by 2005 and reduce the salary bill. 14. Other key Ready Reckoner agreements regarding the supply of teachers within the reformed teacher education system would include the following actions: (i) the intake to the existing and new NCOEs would follow the institutions plan provided in the staff appraisal report and take into consideration the designed capacity under the project (to match demand); (ii) the recruitment of untrained graduate teachers would be the last resort and carried out only in coordination with efforts to retrain untrained teachers while filling the needs on the subject basis; (iii) a recruitment ceiling of 750 graduate teachers (made-up of 400 trained university graduates with PG diplomas and 350 untrained university graduates for special subject needs following prerequisite short-term training of 3 months) would be established. This will involve the gradual increase of PG diploma and BEd graduates to reach an all trained graduate system intake of 750 by year 2003; and (iv) the intake into university post graduate diploma should be according to subject needs identified by the provinces, consolidated by MEHE, and transmitted to the universities by NATE. 15. The main policy targets are outlined in the attached matrix. Government agrees to undertake an annual review of the status of these policies during the implementation of the Teacher Education and Teacher Deployment Project. 16. In conclusion, the policy measures outlined above should allow Sri Lanka to improve the quality, equity, and cost effectiveness of education in schools with minimal impact on the education budget.
