 Annex 11 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND DEPLOYMENT PROJECT DETAILED PROJECT DESCRIPTION Component A: Rationalization of Teacher Deployment (estimated baseline cost US$0.2 million): 1. Teacher recruitment and deployment practices and mechanisms would be modified to improve response to demand while increasing equity and reducing teacher costs. This policy based activity would reactivate the use of existing and updated teacher allocation mechanisms, and formalize the efforts underway since 1995 to standardize the teacher cadre and link it to budgetary allocations. The revised formula takes into consideration actual teacher needs based on student enrollments, the existing teacher cadre, and the annual attrition of teachers from the system (loss due to retirement, death, departure etc.), in allocation of teachers at the primary and secondary levels in all the provinces. The application of the formula and associated mechanisms would allocate a specific cadre of teachers to each province and school and, in turn, trigger annual agreed and fixed budgetary allocations to be determined by a new Cadre Committee (see below) and used by MOF in making payments to the provinces. The agreed program provides that within a period of three years the number of teachers should be rationalized. 2. The objective of this component would be to improve the quality, equity and cost-effectiveness of the staffing of schools through: (i) controlling teacher recruitment below attrition and apply the modified Ready Reckoner to achieve STR targets of 26:1 for primary and 22:1 for secondary by year 2001 (see Annex 3 for details on the application of the RR); (ii) applying the RR consistently to all schools (with stringent provisions for variations to cater for exceptional circumstances); (iii) relating teacher demand projection analysis to teacher supply with annual adjustments; (iv) linking the cadre entitlement for each province to the budget allocation for salaries; (v) utilizing salary savings for quality inputs, particularly in disadvantaged areas; (vi) requiring all teachers entering the service to have successfully completed an accredited teacher education program (with strict criteria being applied to the appointment of untrained teachers, where required, to meet staffing emergencies in specific situations). 3. To achieve the above objectives, the project would strengthen the capacity of MEHE to: (i) collect and analyze data on teacher needs, and carry out demand projections; (ii) develop strategies for linking these needs to national supply capacity; and (iii) regulate the annual teacher trainee intake and deployment of trained teachers. The driving mechanisms would be the annual application of modified RR formula for staff deployment, together with linked budgetary allocations. The salary savings resulting from the stricter application of the RR would be reallocated to quality inputs and maintenance. The goal would be to increase the present national average allocation of 3 percent for quality inputs (but as low as I percent in some provinces) by about 1 percent per year reaching a minimum of 6 percent by the end of the project. 4. MERE, in consultation with Provincial Education Authorities, would be responsible for the annual collection and analysis of teacher demand information and for the preparation of an annual report on short and long-term staffing needs. Provincial authorities would only be allocated teacher salary resources when their annual retrospective staffing and following year staffing plan (cadre) were submitted and agreement on allocation reached. 5. The approved cadre would be determined annually by a Teacher Cadre Committee (TCC) consisting of representatives of MEHE (including the Chairman of the MEHE Teacher Transfers Board), NATE, Ministry of Finance (MOF) which would coordinate the committee, Finance Commission and two Provincial Representatives (nominated by Provincial Directors of Education), in consultation with 83
 Education Service Comnmittee (ESC). The functions and structure of the proposed TCC are outlined in Annex 14. 6. The recurrent teacher salary expenditure allocation for each Province as determined by the TCC would include a margin of 2 percent of approved salary expenditure to cover special circumstances. This margin would commence at a higher rate for those provinces which are under-staffed. For provinces which have more staff than the accepted cadre, a staff equalization plan should be agreed to by MEHE, ESC, MOF and each relevant province. 7. Provinces which were over-staffed and did not meet the agreed staff equalization plan would not be allowed to augment salary expenditures from other sources and would have to consider the student unit cost allocations for various inputs (being developed by MEHE). Provinces which were understaffed and were unable to attract staff under the agreed staff equalization plan would, following the development of a suitable support and incentive plan for targeted schools, be allocated additional funds. As part of the teacher monitoring provisions, the provinces would, in consultation with the ESC, develop during the first year of the project measures to track teacher absenteeism. Teachers who continued to take non-approved or excessive absenteeism (beyond dates mandated) would have their remuneration reviewed. Provinces could then utilize unpaid funds to pay the costs of substitute teachers while being aware that no supplementary salary allocations would be made for teachers with excessive absenteeism. 8. The newly-appointed Transfer Boards created at zonal, provincial and ministry levels under the 1995 National Policy on Teachers Transfers, would have a critical role to play in the redistribution of staff to achieve greater equity (Annex 5). Strict application of the requirements for initial appointment to "non-congenial" (for a minimum of 4 years) and to "difficult" schools (for a minimum of 3 years) and for transfer of teachers after serving a maximum of 8 years in a "congenial" and 6 years in a "very congenial" school, would be essential. Provision would also be made through the initial and continuing education programs for teachers to broaden areas of teaching competence. Secondary teachers should be able to teach a minimum of one major and at least one minor subject, thereby increasing staffing flexibility and MEHE's ability to allocate secondary and collegiate teachers more equitably. 9. MEBE (through the Policy, Planning and Review Division) in consultation with ESC would be responsible for designing a comprehensive plan to attract teachers to, and support teachers in schools in less favorable and/or remote areas. The plan would be based on the newly-formulated categorization of schools into four groups, according to degrees of hardship. This plan would be funded from the savings on teacher salaries (as a result of applying the revised RR) and provide: (i) differential allowances based on the degree of hardships; (ii) differential location allowances on an escalating basis corresponding to the years of service in a particular location; (iii) consideration of years of service in less favorable schools to be used as one of the main criteria for transfer to more favorable schools; (iv) support for teacher travel and housing (local standards); (v) special provision to facilitate teacher access to study opportunities, including payment of partial to full fees and assistance with travel to study centers; and (vi) support for the education of the teacher's children where there is no secondary school available locally. 10. As a further measure to facilitate equitable and flexible deployment, particularly on initial appointment to hardship areas ("non-congenial" and "difficult" schools). Recent increases in salaries for teachers should assist. Other initiatives which should be considered by MEHE and the proposed National Authority on Teacher Education (NATE) include: (i) changing the policy on residential requirement for initial training in undergraduate programs; (ii) increasing the number of non-residential training places; (Mii) increasing stipends for married trainees; (iv) offering housing assistance on first appointment in designated hardship areas for married teachers; and (v) assisting with the secondary education costs of the children of teachers willing to remain in rural areas. For the above activities, the project would support 57 person months of technical assistance outlined in Annex 15. Terms of reference for each consultant have been prepared and are included in the Implementation Volume. 84
 Component B: Rationalization of Structure and Oreanization (estimated baseline cost US$ 0.9million). 11. The objective of this component would be to establish a national framework for an integrated and cost-effective system of teacher education, with coordinating organizations covering all institutions involved in training teachers. The component would strengthen the existing unit of the Teacher Education Commissioner within the MEHE, and establish a new National Authority to develop policy and to coordinate training institutions. It would support restructuring of the system to consist of: (i) a newly- established National Authority on Teacher Education (NATE) for overall policy development, planning, coordination, standardization (including accreditation of programs) and monitoring of teacher education; (ii) three types of training institutions offering initial and continuing teacher education by direct and distance mode - Universities, NEE and National Colleges of Education (NCOEs); and (iii) Teachers Centers (TCs) Type A and Type B (TEIs) which would serve as a resource base for teachers in local areas, a learning and administrative outlet for distance education activities, and a center for the delivery of continuing education courses. Where appropriate, TCs Type A and Type B (TEIs) could also provide a base for advisors working with teachers in local schools and/or for English language courses for teachers in the area. 12. The proposed restructuring would: (i) provide the framework for coordinating all aspects of teacher education on a national basis, including the essential linking of teacher demand with supply through the training institutions; (ii) provide sufficient initial training places to meet the national need for trained teachers; (iii) concentrate initial teacher education in larger and more economical institutions, centrally located in the mnain population centers, thereby increasing the proportion of students in non- residential places; (iv) progressively transform distance mode teacher training from initial certificate to diploma, graduate diploma courses, and to continuing education; (v) achieve a better coverage of staff expertise in areas of specialization within each institution; and (vi) establish and safeguard standards for teacher education programs through a national accreditation and monitoring mechanism. 13. During appraisal agreement was reached to restructure the management of teacher education and to establish NATE. NATE would be a semi-autonomous body responsible to the Minister for Education and Higher Education, within the structure of MEHE, and funded as a separate entity. The principal function of NATE would be to advise the MEHE on major issues relating to teacher education on a national basis. This will involve: (i) developing national policy on, and planning for, teacher education, facilitating the implementation of the integrated national system; (ii) monitoring and research; and (iii) provision of public information on teacher education. The governing body would comprise representatives from: the three types of teacher education institutions - Universities, NIE and NCOEs; the Chief Commissioner for Teacher Education; Provincial Education Authorities; NEC; Ministry of National Planning; Ministry of Finance; Education Service Board; and schools. NATE would have a part-time chairman, a full-time director and secretariat (4 professionals and 5 administrative officers, with provision for secondment of specialized personnel). The project would support the recurrent budget for NATE on a declining basis. Further details on structure, relationships, functions, membership, staffing and funding support for NATE are provided in Annex 17. 14. NATE would have a key role in regulating the supply of trained teachers to meet projected demand in schools as finalized through the Cadre Committee on school staffing entitlements. NATE would make recomnmendations to the Minister, MEHE, annually, on the intake of students by discipline for each teacher education institution. It would also advise the Minister, MEHE, on the budget requirements for each teacher education institution, based on student enrollments and unit costs for different types of progranms. All teacher education programs would be subject to accreditation through NATE. This would involve peer review of programs through a NATE Accreditation Standing Comnmittee. Further, NATE, in consultation with the teacher education institutions, would be responsible for establishing and overview of criteria for the selection, appointment, training and promotion for teacher educators. Two initial responsibilities of NATE would be (i) to assess the equivalency of the current COE 85
 Diploma in Teaching with the Certificates in Teaching awarded by the TTCs and NIE Distance Education, and (ii) to start the process of training needs assessment. NATE would be responsible for coordinating the design and development of a comprehensive continuing education plan and for the accreditation of courses deemed appropriate for recognition towards a further qualification. These activities would require technical assistance. 15. During appraisal Government endorsed: (i) the rationalization of Colleges of Education and Teacher Training Colleges into National Colleges of Education (NCOEs) and TCs both Type A and Type B (TEIs); (ii) the development of some 81 Teacher Centers distributed strategically across all provinces; and (iii) the inclusion of N1E and the faculties/departments of education of the four universities that train teachers (Colombo, Peradeniya, Jaffna and Open University) into the integrated national system. The proposed structure of the reformed teacher education system is outlined in Annex 16. The Office of the Chief Commissioner for Teacher Education would be given a clearer mandate within MEHE and be strengthened through provision of additional staff and equipment. 16. NCOEs would be national institutions, within MEHE, responsible to the Chief Commissioner for Teacher Education (see Annex 18). Their principal focus in the short to medium term would be on initial training to diploma level and on short continuing teacher education courses. These programs would be developed by the NIE national teacher education curriculum committee whose membership includes NCOEs, Universities and schools. NCOEs would normally offer 3 to 4 disciplines for an enrollment of around 700-1,000 students (including 300 third year students in their internship year in schools), with a physical capacity of 500-800, and provision for residential and non-residential students. In the longer term, with NATE's agreement, NCOEs could provide both initial and continuing education courses up to but not including masters level. NCOEs would be given a direct budget allocation, based on NATE's recommendations, and increased financial autonomy, under delegation through the Chief Commissioner for Teacher Education. The Chief Commissioner for Teacher Education would continue to be responsible to the Secretary, MEHE for the overall operation and accountability of NCOEs, in close consultation with NATE and provincial directors of education. The Chief Commissioner would retain responsibility for allocating individual students to NCOEs and for staffing NCOEs, under guidelines agreed through NATE (and in accordance with the provisions of the Teacher Educator Service). For each NCOE there will be an external Conunittee on Continuing Teacher Education, chaired by the NCOE president or vice-president. Membership would include the Director, Continuing Teacher Education; principals of the TCs which are run by that NCOE; the Director, Provincial Education (or nominee); representatives from institutions operating continuing education courses for teachers through the TCs, and from relevant schools. The principal functions of the committee would be to advise the Director, Continuing Teacher Education on the quality and relevance of courses; the allocation of resources; matters relating to teacher access; requirements for future course offerings, and associated resource needs. 17. The Teachers Centers (TCs) would be integral parts of the NCOEs. Each NCOE would have within its organizational structure a number of TCs, assigned according to location and other strategic factors. NCOEs would receive funding for the full operation of the assigned TCs as a specific item within their annual budget. Most TCs would employ a full time principal and about three lecturers (trained in distance teaching), together with administrative support. The full-time TC staff would be part of the staff of the relevant NCOE. The TC head would be directly responsible to the Director, Continuing Teacher Education within each NCOE, would work closely with the province/district education officers and with other training institutions who are offering courses for teachers through that TC. Some 84 Teacher Centers would be developed (renovated, furnished and equipped), having particular regard to demographic and access factors. There would be two types of TCs, Type A TCs (84 in number) with capacity for about 100 teachers at one time, would cater to teachers who can attend on a daily basis (week days and week-ends). Type A TCs would serve as (i) a center for the delivery of continuing education courses (ranging from half day to three weeks); (ii) a resource base for teachers in the local area; (iii) a learning and administrative outlet for distance mode teacher education activities (run by both universities and NIE); (iv) a base for advisors working with teachers in local schools, where appropriate; and (iv) a 86
 center for the delivery of English language teaching for teachers, if required. Type B (TEIs) (3 in number) would offer residential facilities for continuing education courses for teachers without reasonable daily access to Type A TCs. They may also offer the same non-residential services as Type A TCs. Details of the location of the proposed TCs are provided in Annex 19. 18. The Faculties/Departments of Education at the universities would provide initial teacher education both in the disciplines to be taught in schools and in educational methodology, through either a first integrated degree (B.Ed.) or post graduate diploma (Dip.Ed.) programs. In addition, these institutions would, on a selective basis, continue nationally to develop programs to doctorate level. The faculties would continue to operate under the academic structures of their institutions. In order to receive funding for teacher education programs (suggested on a trainee unit cost basis) the selected universities would have to agree to and participate within, the integrated national system, under policies adopted by Govermnent on the advice of NATE. In particular, this would involve the allocation of teacher trainee places consistent with national needs; selection of students based on agreed minimal criteria; agreed student:teacher ratios; and the accreditation of courses by NATE. 19. The National Institute for Education (NIE) would continue to develop programs for initial and continuing teacher education, having a central role in developing courses for delivery by both NIE and NCOEs. Ii would also deliver continuing education programs to upgrade teachers through the distance mode, including diplomas in education, B.Ed degrees, and post-graduate diplomas in education and management. Given the change-over to initial training for all teachers entering the service, NIE's delivery role should decline over time. It would work closely with the Universities and NATE to ensure the compatibility of course offerings and, in the case of the Open University, to share expertise on the design and delivery of courses through the distance mode. NIE would continue to help in the professional development of teacher educators, particularly those in NCOEs and TCs. Professional courses for teacher educators, run by NIE, would be designed on the basis of national subject-based needs assessments, undertaken by NATE, in all NCOEs. (See Staffing and Staff Development, below.). Technical assistance support for NATE and the Comrmissioner of Teacher Education totaling 46 person months are outlined in Annex 15. Component C: UDprading of Teacher Education Programs (estimated baseline cost US$3.7 million) 20. Both initial and continuing programs would be improved, to create a better learning climate in the schools by raising the quality of teaching, and to make the teacher education programs more cost- effective. 21. The objective of the initial (preservice) teacher education program would be to prepare all teachers prior to their entry into the teaching service. Successful completion would be a pre-requisite for all seeking appointment as a teacher. Initial teacher education for secondary teachers would be provided in universities (Post Graduate Diploma in Education and Bachelor of Education) and in National Colleges of Education for primary teachers. Initial teacher education of two years would be conducted in NCOEs followed by a one year internship prior to the award of a Diploma in Teaching. The curriculum is being revised, with ADB assistance, to contain three major areas: general, professional and specialized discipline/subject knowledge (Annex 9). Each NCOE has been assigned geographically in response to enrollments and teacher needs and specific subject requirements by specialization (Annex 20A and 20B). Student enrollment would be based on the projected demand for subject teachers. Entry to NCOEs would require a minimum of 3 subject passes at A level. Each student would select one major with one or two minor subject disciplines. Initial proposals for the subjects and hours allocated to each year of study would reduce the total number of contact periods from the present 35 to between 28 and 23 per semester. Teaching observation and practice in affiliated schools would be an essential component during each year of the program. Within the next ten years, as the country is expected to move towards a degree teacher 87
 force, a three year Bachelor of Education (B.Ed.) should be developed for NCOEs and selected universities, to replace the present two year course in NCOEs. 22. The objective of the continuing (inservice) teacher education program is to improve the quality of teachers already in the teaching service. This sub-component builds on and complements the present distance education program (assisted by SIDA) which has been making important progress in providing a first level certification to untrained teachers. Of the 48 percent of teachers now untrained, about 30,000 will obtain their first certificate in 1996, another 15,000 in 1997 and 10,000 in 1998 (leaving about 15 percent untrained). The continuing education program, as expanded by the Project, would thus continue the important work of giving all untrained teachers a first training, and in addition undertake further upgrading and offer refresher courses for lowly qualified teachers. The content and scope of courses in continuing teacher education would change based upon the outcomes of on-going needs assessments of teachers (para 2.24), through course design and syllabi prepared by NIE utilizing technical assistance. Courses would be offered in all teacher education institutions - Universities, NIE and NCOEs (including TCs). The strategy would be to offer four major types of continuing teacher education courses: (i) upgrading; (ii) broadening; (iii) re-training; and (iv) refresher courses. These courses with costs estimated at US$3.2 million (costed as part of staff development) are outlined in Annex 21. 23. The objective of this component would be to: (i) rationalize the number and location of teacher education institutions to improve regional equity and to meet the projected needs for initial and continuing education; and (ii) to improve the quality of facilities and equipment. Such re-locations would also enable MEHE to increase the number of day students, thus reducing operation costs. All institutions in satisfactory condition would be retained. Also, the existing 250 teacher centers would be reduced to 81. 31. They will, under the coordination of NATE and the Chief Commissioner of Teacher Education, be given more opportunities for self-management, including self-management of their budgets. To assist with this process, training would be given to institution heads, accountants or registrars and other administrators. The budgets would be computerized with standard budget line items in all the institutions. The project would support the review of the system during the first year of the project and offer training to about 20 senior staff and 50 administrative staff. Estimated costs are about $ 50,000 senior staff and $20,000 for administrative staff. Such training would be offered throughout the life of the project. 38. Self-management will allow the instutions realistic amounts for daily operation and maintenance (contrary to the present system where authorization is needed for about every $10.00). Annually, each institution (including the university Faculties of Education and NIE Teacher Education and Distance Education Departments) would prepare and submit to NATE a budget following prescribed categories and agreed norms and unit cost allocations. Once accepted by NATE, these budget lines/items would be included in the operational budgets of the respective universities, NIE and MEHE (subdivided directly to each other institution) and be dedicated for use for teacher training. Within that scenario, each institution will receive every semester about half of its budget (decentralized to the school with increased accounting). The next semester's allocation would only be made following receipt of the previous semester's accounting report. 39. To arrive at that budget allocation stage, two important analyses, under the coordination of NATE, need to be undertaken during the first year of the project and later reviewed annually. The analysis would assess all material, teacher support, books, audio visual and library needs (using some other regional institution allocations as comparators), maintenance and salaries (related to course and teaching loads and support staff ratios to be established) and determine what resources are required to effectively operate a NCOE and TC. The budget would then be broken down into the following categories: (i) new capital inputs to be included in this annual allocation, i.e. furniture and audio visual equipment and other materials; (ii) education inputs required at the start of each academic year (such as books, paper, etc.). All costs would be based on a list of essential requirements by program (to be developed during the first year of the project and which would be supplied by the project and later sustained on an annual basis by the national budget); (iii) the ongoing expenditures (monthly basis) of programs offered, to sustain consumable materials, essential needs and develop a strategy of replacement (progressive manner) of essential teaching materials; (iv) costed lists of essential instructional materials such as library, textbooks and teaching aids for each program (based on norms); and (v) maintenance requirements for the physical infrastructure. The other goal is to have, by the end of the project, institutions which can be self managed and hold their own budgets (as done in similar institutions internationally). Such self management would thus be based on agreed thresholds and allocated fully as part of an annual budget clearly related to an agreed unit cost. Thus, the final budgetary allocation would be determined by the number of trainees trained in each institution. If the number of students is larger or smaller than the previous semester the budget allocations would be adjusted accordingly.  Annex 12 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT OUTCOME, COSTS, AND BENEFITS OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES The main focus for the Project is to rationalize teacher deployment and quality improvements in teacher education. This would be achieved by addressing access, quality, efficiency, cost-effectiveness and sustainability of teacher training programs in Sri Lanka. The following analysis is an attempt to assess the project activities' cost-effectiveness which includes the main actions that would be undertaken, their outcome, and (where possible) estimnates of their costs and benefits. The analysis shows that the Project and the programs it supports have a broadly neutral fiscal impact The declining enrollment in general education (both primary and secondary) due to demographic trends, with the low STR of 24:1 and the excess of teachers in the system, increases the need to rationalize use of education sector resources at the school, provincial, and central levels. At the same time, the tight fiscal condition and the increasing public budget deficit further intensify the need to rationalize Government expenditures and, in turn, put more pressure on the MEHE and the provinces to rationalize teacher numbers and their distribution through recruitment control and consolidation of small schools. Teacher employment rationalization, linking application of the mechanism to resource allocations, would generate substantial sector cost reductions. The summary and detailed tables below show that during the period 1996-2005, aggregate salary expenditure (using the recent 1995 salary scale) could be reduced by Rs 1.6 billion if teacher recruitment is controlled as planned, as the total number of teachers and school administrators would be reduced by 25,000 by 2005. If project-related reforms are carried out fully, and the improvement in education progressively reduces repetition rates substantially, total fiscal savings during the period 1996-2005 could in the best case add further savings of between Rs 2 and 3 billion, making total savings for the 10 years over Rs 4 billion, or US$74 million, equivalent to the costs of the project and incremental expenditures on teacher training. When the unquantifiable (but large) benefits from improved levels of general education in the population at large are factored in, the project benefits are massive. The saving in education salaries would be re-invested in desperately needed quality components such as school supplies and teaching materials, increased teacher training, and to develop support and incentive schemes to motivate teacher transfers to remote and hardship areas.  Annex 13 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT TEACHER CADRE COMMITTEE Context: MEHE, through the Data Processing Branch, determines the cadre entitlement for schools, based on the Ready Reckoner. School inputs are currently collected by Divisional Education Officers, and forwarded to MEHE, which checks school entitlements. Based on advice from MEHE, the Finance Commission incorporates funding provision for salaries into provincial block grants through the Ministry of Finance. In practice, the cadre entitlements (for each school) within a given province are used to establish the overall entitlement of that province and do not necessarily affect the actual staff allocation to individual schools. Proposed changes for the introduction in 1996 (and for use with MIS) provide for Zones to enter school data and for Provinces to collate Zone inputs, prior to a random sample check by MEHE. Project Targets: Teacher recruitment would be control below the attrition and this will lead to a reduction in the number of teachers and the student:teacher ratio will increase to 26:1 for primary and 22:1 by 2001. Rationale for Committee: In order to achieve and maintain the project targets, close monitoring with annual adjustments will be required. The Cadre Comnmittee would broaden the scope for involvement of interested parties in the application of the Ready Reckoner and the allocation of the salaries budget for provinces, annually. Membership: Membership would comprise: (1) the Additional Secretary (Administration), Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MEHE) chair; (2) a representative of the National Authority for Teacher Education; (3) two Provincial Directors of Education (Rotate in every three years); (4) a representative of the Secretary to the Ministry of Provincial Councils; (5) two representatives of the Secretary to the Ministry of Finance one of whom shall be from the Planning Division and the other from the Budget Division; (6) Director of Policy, Planning and Review Division, Ministry of Education; (7) Chairman/Secretary of Education Service Committee; (8) Chief Commissioner of the Colleges of Education; and (9) Representative of the Finance Commission. Functions: The principal functions of the Cadre Committee would be as follows; * to review the annual student and staff projections prepared by the Data Processing Branch, MERE; * to review and make recommendations to the Secretary, MEHE, on the annual adjustments to the STR which would be required to meet the project STR targets by year 2000; * to review the cadre requests, on a province by province basis, against the Ready Reckoner entitlements; * to determine annual cadre entitlements and linked salaries budget for each province, together with any tolerance levels deemed to be appropriate, and to recommend accordingly to the Secretary MEHE and the Secretary, MOFP; * to monitor progress towards meeting the project STR targets on a province by province basis and, if necessary, make recommendations to the Secretary, MEBE on strategies for achieving the targets within the agreed timeframe,; * to review the effectiveness of the National Policy on Teachers Transfers in achieving an equitable distribution of teachers, nationally; * to advise NATE, annually, on short, medium and long-term projected teacher demand, having particular regard to requirements by discipline, medium of instruction and provincial distribution; * to prepare an annual report to the Secretary and Minister, MEHE and the Secretary and Minister of Finance on the staffing and the salaries budget status of each province in relation to the project targets. 102

 -Annex 16 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT NATIONAL AUTHORITY ON TEACHER EDUCATION The National Authority on Teacher Education (NATE) would be established as an integral part of the restructuring of teacher education to form a co-ordinated national system. NATE would be responsible to the Minister of Education and Higher Education for overall policy development, planning, co-ordination and monitoring (including accreditation of programs) of the national system of teacher education. Facilitating Implementation of a National System * anticipating and addressing potential impediments to implementation of a national system; * relating teacher demand to supply, including allocation of student numbers by course to institutions; * collating budget estimates for providing institutions, based on unit cost analysis; * co-ordinating professional activities among providing institutions; * co-ordinating assistance from overseas agencies, including Link Institutions; * co-ordinating and approving scholarship awards; * establishing criteria for selection and promotion of staff; * establishing criteria for appointment of heads of institutions Monitoring and Research * establishing and maintaining mechanisms for accreditation of training programs; * reviewing student intakes, progress and outputs (relating to demand); * reviewing expenditure patterns and unit cost; * promoting and co-ordinating research activities relating to teacher education; * initiating and co-ordinating follow-up and appraisal of activities.  Annex 20 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT Continuing Education Programs 1. In today's society, continuing education is extremely important within all professions. The amount of knowledge is changing and increasing all the time. A basic education or graduation cannot last for a professional career. A person with a basic education or graduation has to be up-graded, broadened, refreshed and even re-trained to adjust to new developments within the society. This is also valid for teachers. What is supposed to be taught in the classrooms is changing continually. 2. To enable teachers to remain conversant with modem trends and subject content, MEHE has decided to expand its in-service education provincial programs and to offer more comprehensive continuing education to all teachers in Sri Lanka. This project proposes four types of continuing education: upgrading, broadening, retraining and refreshing. All four are equally important. These types may be offered through distance (mixed) self-learning mode, regular contact courses or sessions, and intensive residential courses. 3. The basic concept of offering a broad range of continuing education programs for teachers is essential if Sri Lankan schools are to improve their quality. Therefore, within this project, funding is provided for the development and delivery of the four different types of continuing education: (a) The upgrading courses would keep teachers up-to-date in subject content and methodology by providing structured courses which would (i) largely fulfill the requirements of the Teachers Service Minute, and (ii) allow untrained, partially trained and Basic Certificated teachers to qualify for a Diploma in Teaching equivalent to the NCOE award. These courses would be offered through a combination of distance learning mode and intensive face-to-face training (both residential and non-residential). For teachers who have completed Basic Training only through distance mode, an intensive residential component of three weeks duration would be required, rather than further distance mode training. Such residential upgrading would be conducted in Teacher Centres (Type BlTEIs) and in NCOEs. It is intended that project funds would be used by NIE to develop and print the 15 modules for distance education (which would also be the basis for the three week intensive residential alternative. Such residential courses would give preference to those teachers who had not received previous residential- based training.). (b) The broadening courses would encourage teachers to expand their knowledge and skills in order to obtain additional qualifications. Courses would continue to be offered by universities and NIE, leading to recognized awards. This project would (i) expand the range of courses available by funding the preparation of undergraduate level distance mode courses to be identified by NATE; (ii) finance the preparation of specialised regular contact courses; and (iii) assist in financing the organization and administration of continuing education. NCOEs and Teacher Centres (Type A) could also be used for the contact portions of the distance mode courses. (c) The re-training courses would (i) allow teachers to adapt their area of specialization to meet particular demands for specific subject teachers, and (ii) continue the provincial in-service training which could satisfy some of the requirements of the Teachers Service Minute. Project funding would only be used for the former; such specialized study could be taken on a full-time or part-time basis. The need for such re- training is expected to diminish as more teachers are prepared initially (pre-service) in accordance with identified subject demand. 117
 (d) The refeshing activities would cater to the identified needs of local teachers. Such local needs will be identified through provision of technical assistance, and training would be managed and conducted at minimal costs through short sessions (half day to two days) given in TCs and/or in schools. Such activities would, for example, introduce teachers to revised and new programs and strengthen the professional identity of teachers. Refreshing activities would be contact sessions in the form of workshops or seminars. One of their purposes is to fulfill local needs, consequently the content of the refreshing seminars would vary from one area to the other. Another purpose is to strengthen the teacher's identity and for that purpose the social component of meeting together in groups is very important. Refreshing activities would not lead to any formally recognized award, although they may, over time, become recognized for purposes of the Teachers Service Minute. The curriculumn for continuing education has to be very flexible. It should be the framework within which the teachers have a possibility to adapt and adjust their knowledge and skills in accordance with scientific developments and with development within the society. Initially, the content of the courses would be based on (i) the outcome of the needs assessments and (ii) the requirements of the Teachers Service Minute. For upgrading and retraining courses, programs would be designed to cover methodology and subject areas where the teachers are teaching or want to teach. For broadening courses, there would be other programs as well, such as health and nutrition, gender issues, computer science, languages and new knowledge within the professional area. For refresher courses, the main purpose is to cater to local needs identified by the teacher, parents, pupils and the local community. In a long term perspective, all institutions involved in teacher education should be involved in developing ideas for continuing education courses of all types. These ideas would be sent to NATE for evaluation and selection. The selected ideas would be assigned by NATE for further development, processing, and implementation by NIE, NCOEs, or universities. 6. NATE will be responsible for the coordination of the needs and delegation of the development of course material and course design to NIE, universities or NCOEs. The project would provide TA to assist in training of staff who would be responsible for course layout/design and development of the distance education self-instructional material. TA would assist in designing the set-up necessary (including infrastructure, logistical delivery, monitoring mechanism and training of on-site tutors and facilitators) to meet the demands of continuing education in general and distance education in particular. In total , 40 international consultant months are assigned for design and development of continuing education programs, about half of which are proposed for distance education. There would also be 120 national consultant months. 7. Distance education will be used as one of the delivery modes in three of the four types of continuing education. The Department of Distance Education and the Department of Teacher Education within NIE as well as Open University are at present offering courses that can be classified mainly as upgrading and broadening courses by means of distance education. These courses can and should be continued in the new program of continuing education. Examples are B.Ed., Dip. Ed. and M.Ed. upgrading courses offered by the Department of Teacher Education, NIE and Open University; the Basic Certifciation courses (which could be extended to Diploma) and some broadening courses (e.g., English, Tamil and Sinhala as a second language) offered by the Department of Distance Education, NIE. The basic and broadening courses offered by means of Distance Education at the Department of Distance Education, NIE, are currently funded by SIDA. The agreement made between SIDA and Sri Lanka is effective through December 1998. 8. The project's teacher education programs include both initial and continuing education activities in order to enhance the quality of education. The linkages between both programs will be better coordinated to ensure that teachers can improve their qualifications through one or a combination of initial and continuing training courses. To make sure that the content of the upgrading, broadening and re-training courses is suitable and supports teacher improvement, a cross-creditation of such courses will be undertaken by NATE. However, refreshing sessions and other short courses would not be included in such cross-creditation. C:\SRILANKAlSAR496'ANNEXES4\ANEX20.DOC 119

 Annex 23 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT Criteria for Staff Development Criteria for Appointment of Heads of Teacher Education Institutions The following are some of the general criteria which need to be considered in the open selection of heads, administrators or department heads of teacher education institutions. This list needs to be modified/elaborated on from time to time: * Demonstrated ability as a teacher, and p-referably as a teacher educator * Ability to identify problems, consider a%ernative solutions and to make decisions based on substantiated evidence. * Demonstrated ability to play an active role in preparing and implementing institutional plans and programs. * Knowledge of, and ability to implement, management principles and techniques for increasing the effectiveness and efficiency of an institution. * Demonstrated experience in working effectively with others, in molding teams and in professional leadership. * Proven ability to work with other managers/senior administrators within the relevant authorities responsible for teacher education, and with members of government boards/councils. * Strong academic qualifications (preferably a Master's degree), and evidence of involvement in professional bodies. * Professional qualifications in education, and preferably in teacher education or management. * Effective personal and communication skills with adults. * Personality characteristics, social skills, and community participation/contribution which will enhance effective leadership. Criteria for Appointment of Staff as Teacher Educators The following are some of the general criteria which need to be considered in the open selection of teacher educators. This list needs to be modified/elaborated from time to time: * Ability to think critically and creatively and to guide others in the learning process. * Minimum of five years' experience in teaching at the level (primary or secondary) and in the discipline/subject to which he/she will be assigned in the institution. * Specialized knowledge in his/her subject field or professional/pedagogical area. * Minimum academic qualifications of a Bachelor's degree and Post-Graduate Diploma, preferably in Education; except for some specialist subject teachers (for example: art, music, technical studies, physical education) who have had no opportunity to obtain higher academic awards. * Demonstrates competence and effectiveness in his/her teaching and in relationships with others, including desirable values and attitudes. * Shows a commitment to teaching and to facilitating learning. * Evidence of involvement in on-going professional development. 126
 Criteria for the Selection of Candidates for Staff Development a) For Long-Term Fellowships: * Requiring academic degree/diploma in a specialized field or discipline to be able to teach subject content at post-secondary level. * Requiring professional degree or diploma at the relevant level. * Below the age of 45 years at the time of selection. * Demonstrates mental ability and academic study habits suitable for further rigorous advanced level study. * As a teacher educator, contributes significantly to the life and activities of the institution * Meets the criteria for a teacher educator, including teaching experience in schools. * Demonstrates potential for effective career in teacher education, either as a staff member or administrator. * Able to obtain acceptance by a tertiary institution acceptable to the employing authority. * Prepared to contribute to raising the quality and efficiency of their institution b) For Short-Term Internship or Assignment: * Demonstrates ability to contribute significantly to the life of the institution. * Shows willingness to learn through such an internship and to assist other staff on return. * Can propose specific activities, research, teaching or related experiences which he/she wishes to undertake during the internship/assignment directly relevant to his responsibilities and duties in the institution. * Prepared to disseminate knowledge and skills gained following his/her return.  Annex 24 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT TEACHER EDUCATOR STAFF DEVELOPMENT In the revised system of teacher education, staff in all institutions conducting teacher education programs will need training. Such training will vary from a few days or weeks observation to several years' full-time study leading to recognized degrees. A training plan should be developed by the Project Coordinating Unit and NATE to cover nearly all teacher educators in all institutions (universities, NIE, NCOEs and TCs). ANALYSIS OF ACADEMIC CHARACTERISTICS The initial step, which must be continually up-dated, has been to identify the academic characteristics of a large sample (about 87 percent -- from all but one university and one COE) of staff employed in institutions in 1995. The data collected on 613 teacher educators have been partially analysed and indicate that: * 38 percent of the respondents were under 45 years of age in 1995; these are the only staff eligible for long- term further education. They, and other staff not surveyed or yet to be appointed, should form the data base for on- going analysis to prepare a staff development plan for long-term study. The remaining staff (over 45 years) should be given opportunities for short-term study and observation. Of this group of over 200 teacher educators, the following numbers indicate the potential magnitude of training which may be required for existing academic staff: Staff requiring Staff under 45 Staff over 45 First degree 29(5%) 73(12%) Diploma in Education(with BA) 3 3(5%) 47(8%) Diploma in Education(with MA) 25(4%) 25(4%) Miasters' Degree 116(20%) 153(24%) Post-Masters' study 30(5%) 66(11%) * 65 percent of staff consider that their first degree (major subject), and 16 percent that their Masters' degree field, is not relevant to the subjects which they teach in teacher education institutions. This needs to be investigated further to determine whether adjustments in teaching duties would make greater use of existing expertise. Some re-training may be needed. Following any re-assignments, a more detailed examination will be needed of whether any of the remaining teacher educators should receive training in a different discipline. * 40 percent of the teacher educators are not able to speak or write in English. This would hamper the possibilities for study abroad. If any of these are in the eligible group, they should be offered training within the country. FURTHER ANALYSIS Additional analyis is required of the existing sample data: * correlate the responses to each part of question 11 with those of question 13 * correlate responses to questions 13 and 14 * analyse the subjects/disciplines obtained in their degree with those which they now teach and propose adjustments in teacher education teaching assignments accordingly * analyse those lecturers who were teachers, to determine at what level and subject specialisation they taught, whether these teaching experiences are most relevant to their teacher educator duties and propose adjustments accordingly * seek data on which lecturers have teaching experience at the primary level and correlate this with their academic qualifications and their current teacher educator teaching responsiblities. 128
 * obtain data from senior administrators in each institution to determine their specific training requirements, especially for short management and financial training in country. Once the Project becomes effective, and as new staff (including those in Teacher Centres) are appointed, this data base will need to be up-dated continually so that an annual analysis can be made. PREPARING A STAFF DEVELOPMENT PLAN The two major categories for staff development, whether in-country or abroad, are: (i) fellowships for long-term study; and (ii) short-term assignments and attachments. Criteria for eligibility (Annex 23) for both categories need to be refined and agreed as soon as possible. The following steps will need to be taken: For Long-term Fellowships: 1. Up-date and verify the numerical data with the actual individual responses through a print out of the coded data base of the teacher educators who are under 45 years of age. This is best done by institution, since these data bases will later need to be compared with the recommended priorities submitted by the heads of each institution. 2. The recommendations from heads of institutions for priority consideration should be assessed by: a. comparing the data base for those under 45 with the priority ranked recommendations and assign a new rank order within each institution; b. group this new rank-ordered sub-set into levels of formal study (First degree, Post-Graduate Dip.Ed, Post-Graduate, Other) and prepare a new sub-set across all institutions; c. verify from both the heads' recommendations and the data base, that this new sub-set is accurate; 3. Establish this new sub-set by level as the basis for determining eligibility for study in-country, in-region and ex-region. 4. Prepare a list of each sub-set, according to the location proposed for study. 5. Determine, in consultation with NATE and appropriate authorities, the most appropriate levels and specific institutions at each training location for each nominated teacher educator. 6. Prepare a time schedule for each teacher educator to begin a fellowship. Obtain agreement from the nominee. For those nominees scheduled to commence study during the first two years of the project (late 1996-1997), this detailed schedule should be presented to IDA or the funding agency no later than at the time of formal project negotiations. 7. For those persons nominated for study commencing in 1996, initiate discussions with the institution where study is proposed to obtain admission and other logistical requirements. 8. Obtain the required approvals from within Government and IDA or other funding agency by March 1996 for each nominee for 1996-1997. 9. Make appropriate logistical arrangements for each nominees' study whether at home or abroad. Short-term Assignments: 1. From the prioritized lists prepared by each head of institution, initially select 50 percent of candidates for short-term assignment or attachment. 2. Rank order these candidates according to their eligibility to meet the agreed criteria (see Annex 23), irrespective of the institution in which they serve. 3. Group candidates according to type of experience and/or possible location of attachment. 4. Prepare, by the time of negotiations, an initial list of about 40 candidates intended to be offered attachments during 1996-1997, grouped by location. 5. Initiate discussions with possible recipient institutions and determine conditions and timing for each group. 6. Obtain concurrence of candidates, and approval from appropriate authorities. 7. Finalise all arrangements and begin assignments. 129

 Annex 26 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT STUDIES AND MONITORING Funding assumption: 515,000 per month plus 55,000 travel (national inputs would cost less). Six studies would be undertaken during the course of the project. Five of the studies would relate directly to monitoring the progress and impact of policy initiatives and associated strategies which are central to the effective implementation of the project. One study (which could comprise a number of smaller studies) would focus on the investigation of areas which could have relevance to the planning of a future project. The outlines for the proposed studies are as follows: 1. ImDact of Rationalization of Teacher Denloyment Policies Purpose: to review the impact of agreed policies and strategies for teacher deployment on resource allocation, the equitable staffing of schools, and appraise the effectiveness of criteria for teacher progression and promotion. Scope: M review of staff cadres by school, district, zone and province; * analysis of teaching staff deployment by subject and medium of instruction; e analysis of staff deployment to non-congenial and difficult schools, including years of service and gender, and related allowances; e assessment of overall teacher demand and supply projections against staffing formula (Ready Reckoner); e analysis of deployment of non-teaching staff; e determine level of salaries saving resulting directly from implementation of changes to deployment policy; * critical appraisal of criteria for teacher progression and promotion. Timeframe: up to four months - to be undertaken in years 2 and 4 of the project. Responsibility: The Cadre Conunittee would be responsible for oversighting the conduct of the study and for the collection and collation of relevant data. Consultant Expertise: to include (i) proven capacity to work with senior administrative, planning and finance personnel; (ii) extensive experience in matters relating to teacher demand and supply and to the operation of Government systems for teacher employment, deployment, progression and promotion; (iii) knowledge of data bases for teacher information; (iv) record of achievement in working to agreed deadlines; (v) high level of skill in spoken and written English. Estimated Cost: up to $70,000. 2. Trainee Access, Progression, Repetition and Attrition Purpos: monitor patterns of student access, progression, repetition and attrition and to appraise resource and service implications. Scope: * apply to both initial training and continuing education; * examination of resource implications of patterns of progression, repetition and attrition in initial training; * analysis of access patterns for continuing education in direct, distance and residential modes. Timeframe: up to three months, during second half of project, preferably years 3 and 5. Responsibility: NATE would be responsible for oversighting the conduct of the study and for collection and collation of data. Consultant Expertise: to include (i) proven capacity to work with senior administrative and academic personnel; (ii) competence in the design and conduct of interviews and surveys, in the use of data analysis techniques 132
 (including establishing data bases on student-related information), and in unit cost analyses; (iii) record of achievement in working to agreed deadlines; (iv) high level of skill in spoken and written English. Estimated Cost: up to $50,000. 3. Professional DeveloDment of Teachers - Continuin2 Education Purpose: to identify professional development needs of teachers, as the basis for designing relevant continuing education programs, and to monitor and appraise the impact of such programs. Scope: Phase 1: * pilot study of five zones to design and test the feasibility of methodology for assessing teacher needs for continuing education, as required under the Teaching Service Minute; * national study of the perceived needs of teachers, based on methodology developed in the pilot study, to identify relevant areas for professional development. Phase 2: * analysis of participation rates and attendance patterns; * appraisal of relationship of identified needs to identified continuing education programs (Phase l); * analysis of operation and utilization of locations by different agencies; * examination of resource utilization, including unit costs; * appraisal of impact of teacher access to continuing education on quality of teaching; * analysis of relationship between continuing education and requirements under Teaching Service Minute and impact on progression within the service. Timeframe: up to five months, with Phase 1 being undertaken during the first year of the project and Phase 2 in years 3 and 5 of project. Responsibility: NATE would be responsible for oversighting the conduct of the study and for collection and collation of required data. Consultant Expertise: to include (i) experience in the field of continuing (inservice) education for teachers; (ii) proven capacity to work with senior administrative and academic personnel; (iii) competence in the design and conduct of interviews and surveys, in the use of data analysis techniques (including establishing a data bases on teacher needs), and in unit cost analyses; (iii) record of achievement in working to agreed deadlines; (iv) high level of skill in spoken and written English. Estimated Cost: up to $70,000 4. Teacher Education Fundin2 Scope: * analysis of recurrent expenditure, with item breakdown (eg., salaries, residential, maintenance; * review of student stipend cost and private costs for teacher education trainees; * analysis of unit costs of programs, including differences in types of institutions, programs and modes of delivery; * review of institutional budget systems and accountability. Timeframe: up to three months in second half of project. Responsibility: NATE would be responsible for oversighting the conduct of the study and for the collection and collation of required data. Consultant Expertise: to include (i) proven capacity to work with senior admninistrative and academic personnel; (ii) extensive experience in financial analysis in education, preferably in tertiary contexts; (iii) familiarity with international practice for determining student:staff ratios, involving full-time and part-time students and direct, distance and residential modes; competence in use of data analysis techniques (including unit cost program costing and analysis by program and student; (iii) record of achievement in working to agreed deadlines; (iv) high level of skill in spoken and written English. Estimated Cost: up to $55,000. 133
 5. Effectiveness of NATE and National System of Teacher Education Purpose: to review the effectiveness of NATE and integrated national system for teacher education and to make recommendations on any changes in structure, function or modus operandi that may be required. Scope: * appraisal of performance against stated functions for each agency; * appraisal of relationship among agencies; * review of data base network; * review of system resource needs, distribution, utilization and accountability; * advice on need for any modification of structure, functions or modus operandi. Timeframe: up to three months - in year 3 and year 5 of project. Responsibility: an independent Steering Committee, appointed by the Minister, MEHE, and convened through the Project Co-ordinating Unit, would be responsible for oversighting the study. Consultant Expertise: to include (i) extensive experience in senior executive positions, preferably including co- ordinating bodies; (ii) proven capacity to work with senior administrative and academic personnel; (iii) strong analytical expertise, particularly in relation to appraising effectiveness in terms of policy, planning, and co- ordination in education context; (iv) record of achievement in working to agreed deadlines; (v) high level of skill in spoken and written English. Estimated Cost: up to $55,000. 6. Study of Oualitv Needs Purpose: to undertake a review/analysis of the quality needs required by grade, subject and classroom to ensure sufficient quality inputs at the primary, secondary and collegiate levels. The goal would be to identify, under the co-ordination of NIE the essential and optional quality inputs, establish lists and develop individual school strategies to meet these goals. The analysis would develop, by level, unit cost requirement for the supply of the essential and optional quality inputs (per student, classroom, teacher). It would also determine mechanisms to monitor the allocation, the use and replenishment of the quality inputs. The analysis would compare the quality inputs in about four other countries, in the region, and ensure that the best potential allocations are arrived at. Specific lists of quality inputs would be prepared and these would be monitored by the provinces annually. Timeframe: Within six months after project effectiveness. Responsibility: MEHE and NIE. Expertise: National consultants knowledgeable in curriculum and essential educational materials, equipment etc. needed to effectively teach the various subjects and effectively equip students, teachers and classrooms and laboratories. Estimated Costs: US$20,000. 7. Project Preparation Purpose: to undertake investigations in areas which have the potential for inclusion in a future project. Scope: possible scope of study/studies to include primary, secondary and tertiary levels, curriculum and assessment, resources, infrastructure, management, staff development and finance. Thmeframe: up to 5 months - allocated according to selected range of investigation. Respondbility: initially through the Project Co-ordinatmg Unit.  Annex 29 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT Government Procurement Capacity 1. Government capacity to handle the procurement proposed under the project is stiUl weak although improving. All tenders undertaken for education have been decentralized to a MEHE tender committee. In the past that tender committee suffered from inefficiencies and duplication of services resulting in long delays with the preparation of tender documentation and bid reviews. The delays were largely caused by the multiple levels of review and the numerous tender and technical committees (a minimum of two per tender and staffed with different persons who met separately) with the result that MEHE took on average 8 to 12 months to process a tender. That followed by the delivery period which lasted from six months to over one year resulting in most procurement activities taking close to two year to complete. The tenders also suffered from external political pressures making procurement a difficult task. 2. Following discussions undertaken during the implementation of the ongoing General Education Project MEHE has agreed to the following adjustments which would be used during the proposed project: a) to replace the temporary and multiple tender and technical committees by a permanent tender committee and to establish three or four permanent technical committees (area and subject based). Both committees (tender and technical) would meet jointly thus reducing the time lag for tender preparation and tender analysis. The joint conunittee would also be given time limits for each processing step. b) The IDA Bidding documentation would be used for all ICB tenders and the provisional NCB tenders prepared by ICTAD would be for used for all the NCB tenders. c) MEHE has agreed to establish procurement preparation and review calendars which would respect the tender periods listed in the bidding documentation. Thus, on the basis that he above proposed measures it is believed that the MEHE, with some national technical assistance will have the capacity to undertake the required project procurement activities. 3. To achieve the above the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) would be staffed with a director, an architect (with procurement and tender processing experience) and an trained procurement officer. These posts should be filled prior to or at a minimum by project effectiveness to ensure timely implementation of the large tender and procurement actions required. The MEHE/School Works Service would assist with the recruitment of technical staff for the project. 4. Tenders for civil works would be tendered using: (a) International Competitive Bidding (ICB) for all works related to the construction and the rehabilitation and expansion of the NCOEs and renovation works for the University of Jaffna; (b) National Competitive Bidding (NCB) for all works under US$300,000 (related to the refurbishment and expansion of the Colombo Faculty of Education and for the instaUation or the nation-wide refurbishment/installation of the TCs type A); and (c) using three bids for smal refurbishment and rehabilitation contracts 5. In conformity with the agreements made during appraisal the following bidding procedures will be used: for all procurement using ICB: (a) IDA standard bidding documentation will be used for civil works and equipment; (b) all procurement documentation will be standardized and coordinated by PCU in consultation with the permanent tender and technical teams; and (c) that, tenders only be called folowing IDA review of the tender documentation packages. For all procurement under NCB: standard documentation agreed to by IDA (draft ICTAD bidding documentation) would to be used and in that context the PCU/School Works would: (i) provide provincial services with standard documentation that 141
 would have to be used; and (ii) retain an overview during the implementation period to ensure timely processing. 6. The PCU will coordinate and have an overview of all project procurement activities (tenders, contracts and payments for architectural and technical studies, furniture, equipment, books, education materials, printing contracts, technical assistance, training and studies) utilizing the IDA guidelines and in accordance with the procurement threshold outlined in Annex 25. All ICB tender documentation will require a prior IDA review and for the NCB the initial tender documentation (or if substantive changes are made to later tenders) would be reviewed and commented by IDA prior to tenders.. PCU will be the contact office for IDA during project implementation. 7. To assist PCU with the process the procurement activities funds have been included in the project for the services of national and international procurement specialists.  Annex 34 SRI LANKA TEACHER EDUCATION AND TEACHER DEPLOYMENT PROJECT IDA SUPERVISION PLAN 1. Progress Reviews and Reporting: The Ministry of Education and Higher Education would assume the implementation, monitoring and reporting responsibilities for this project. These tasks would largely be delegated to the project coordination unit (PCU) which would assume the day-to-day overview of the project. PCU would also prepare the monthly status report required by the External Resources Department and summarize these into semester reports for IDA in December and June of each year starting December 1996. Based on the experience of the ongoing General Education Project, the report would include financial and data tables and status summaries using formats suitable for both the Government and IDA. This joint effort would reduce paper work and result in consistency of reporting and facilitate the gradual transfer of supervision responsibilities to the IDA Resident Mission Staff in Colombo starting the second year of project implementation. 2. The progress reports would include the following: summary of implementation progress (write- up and tables) listing the status of each project component and comparing it with the plans; financial summary by component (including funds spent, committed, actual commitments versus planned and proposals for the next semester); update of the implementation schedule, project implementation plan and indicators (showing actual versus planned); list of issues and problems that have arisen and proposal of options for their resolution; data table on activities (planned, actual, proposed for the next with estimated funding needs) of such activities as civil works, training, fellowships, studies and technical assistance; and finally, the status of credit disbursements. Every semester the report would assess if the project objectives are still realistic and advise if new circumstances (political or administrative) are affecting the implementation of the project goals as set-out at the time of appraisal. The joint reporting format will be finalized during the start-up seminar. 3. IDA would review the progress of the project a minimum of twice yearly and if possible three times yearly. One of these mission would be a more comprehensive annual review during which all aspects of the project would be closely reviewed. During the first review of each year a joint mission would be undertaken with the other Donors contributing to the project. A mid-term review is scheduled about 2 years after project effectiveness, (about July 1998) at which time the project objectives would be closely reviewed and needed adjustments to the project content and implementation steps would be undertaken. 4. The proposed project would be monitored and evaluated from the perspectives of inputs, process, outputs and impact. The input evaluation would focus on whether the required resources are in place to implement the program of activities and services. Input information would be monitored and assessed continuously (reported quarterly, semi-annually "semester reports" and annually) to identify the delivery input so that problems could be resolved in a timely manner. The process evaluation would examine the approaches used in the training, service delivery and recipient participation and review the levels of performance comparable to project inputs and suggest remediation of non-responsive inputs. The output evaluation would focus on the immediate results of activities, as demonstrated, for examples improvements of exam results in schools where the qualifications of teachers have been improved etc.. The output evaluation would focus on the program outputs in the terms of programs and review such factors as: the number to trainees per programs; if the equitable distribution of trained teachers is improving; whether student teacher ratios are being adjusted; and linkages between the budget and cadre allocations within each province. S. The above evaluation steps would be supplemented by studies (outlined in annex 23). These studies would assess the impact of the teacher educational and teacher deployment policies being 150
 implemented. Since this is a very technical project supervision by IDA staff should be guided by a experienced educator supported by an education economist who would assess the project's progress. In view of the large civil works activities in this project, during the annual review the latter specialists should also be assisted by an architect (first year external specialist and afterwards by national specialists). 6. The IDA project supervision would be allocated an annual average of 16 staff weeks for in- country and desk supervision of this project. However, the number of staff weeks required during the first two years would be about 20 reducing to about 12 during the third and fourth years of implementation. doc.repnme: Sri Lanka - Teacher Education and Teacher Deployment Project
doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Teacher Education and Teacher Deployment Project, based on policy initiatives agreed between the government and IDA over the past year, are to improve the quality, cost-effectiveness and coverage of education in Sri Lanka, by: 1) improving education attainment and equity; 2) making the system more efficient; 3) making more effective use of education expenditure; 4) improving the quality of teacher education; and 5) making the teacher training system more cost-effective. The project will consist of the following components: 1) rationalization of teacher deployment; 2) rationalization of structure and organization of teacher education; 3) upgrading of teacher education programs; 4) strengthening of staff and management; 5) strengthening and upgrading of the teacher training institutions; 6) strengthening the management of teacher training institutions; 7) studies and monitoring; and 8) project coordination.
